    <!-- 1. Overview -->
    <section id="sec-1">
      <h2>1. Overview</h2>
      <p>
        In the context of the 4.0 Industrial Revolution, data is considered the “new oil” of the knowledge economy. 
        Effective data mining has become a core competency in healthcare, education, economics, public administration, 
        and community development. However, many organizations and communities in Vietnam still face significant challenges.
      </p>

      <div class="callout">
        <p><strong>Key challenges:</strong></p>
        <ul>
          <li>Lack of systematic, practical guidance documents in Vietnamese.</li>
          <li>Uneven data analysis capacity, still dependent on manual tools (basic Excel, paper reports).</li>
          <li>Lack of connection between modern analysis tools (R, Python, Power BI, Stata) and practical applications in community management, public health, and sustainable development.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <div class="callout">
        <p><strong>Recent international studies show:</strong></p>
        <ul>
          <li><em>Al Nuaimi &amp; Awofeso (2024):</em> Data and Business Intelligence (BI) are drivers for improving the efficiency of the healthcare system.</li>
          <li><em>Dicuonzo et al. (2022):</em> BI plays a central role in the digital transformation of healthcare.</li>
          <li><em>Mansoor &amp; Dar (2024):</em> The application of BI helps optimize the management of clinical testing processes.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <p>
        Therefore, it is necessary to develop an <strong>academic and practical handbook</strong> to guide data processing and analysis for the community, 
        combining theory, tools, methods, and practical illustrations.
      </p>
    </section>

    <!-- 2. Objectives -->
    <section id="sec-2">
      <h2>2. Objectives</h2>

      <h3>2.1. General Objective</h3>
      <div class="card">
        <p>
          To compile a <strong>practical handbook</strong> that is scientific, academic, 
          but easy to access, to enhance the data processing and analysis capacity 
          for communities, social organizations, and management agencies in Vietnam in the digital age.
        </p>
      </div>

      <h3>2.2. Specific Objectives</h3>
      <div class="card">
        <ol>
          <li>Present a systematic theory of data, data quality, and data governance in the community.</li>
          <li>Guide the use of popular tools: <em>Excel / Power Query / Power Pivot, Power BI, Stata, R / RMarkdown / RShiny, basic Python, Quarto / Positron</em>.</li>
          <li>Introduce analysis methods: from descriptive statistics, inferential analysis to Big Data and Business Intelligence (BI).</li>
          <li>Illustrate through practical <em>case studies</em>: 
            <ul>
              <li>Application of BI in test management (Navify);</li>
              <li>Big Data in the health supply chain;</li>
              <li>Community dashboard using Power BI;</li>
              <li>Public health data analysis using RShiny.</li>
            </ul>
          </li>
          <li>Provide a training framework, sample datasets, exercises, and implementation guidance.</li>
        </ol>
      </div>
    </section>

    <section id="sec-3">
      <h2>3. Scope and Audience</h2>

      <div class="callout">
        <p><strong>Beneficiaries:</strong></p>
        <ul>
          <li>Healthcare workers</li>
          <li>Statisticians – managers</li>
          <li>Civil society organizations</li>
          <li>Students – young researchers</li>
          <li>Government officials</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <div class="callout">
        <p><strong>Scope of application:</strong></p>
        <ul>
          <li>Public health</li>
          <li>Community governance</li>
          <li>Education</li>
          <li>Socio-economics</li>
          <li>Environment</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <div class="callout">
        <p><strong>Limitations:</strong></p>
        <p>
          The handbook focuses on <em>applied data practice</em>, 
          and does not replace statistics textbooks or advanced programming materials.
        </p>
      </div>
    </section>

    <!-- 4. Proposed Structure -->
    <section id="sec-4">
      <h2>4. Proposed Structure</h2>

      <!-- Part I -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part I. Data Fundamentals and Data Governance</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Concepts and classification of data (structured, unstructured, semi-structured).</li>
          <li>Data lifecycle: collection – cleaning – storage – analysis – reporting – application.</li>
          <li>Data quality: attributes (accuracy, completeness, timeliness, integrity).</li>
          <li>FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable).</li>
          <li>Data security and community research ethics.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <!-- Part II -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part II. Data Processing Tools</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Excel &amp; Power Query/Power Pivot.</li>
          <li>Power BI for reports and dashboards.</li>
          <li>Stata: analysis of social and health quantitative data.</li>
          <li>R &amp; RMarkdown &amp; RShiny: from basic analysis to web applications.</li>
          <li>Python: pandas, matplotlib, scikit-learn for basic data analysis and automation.</li>
          <li>Quarto/Positron: reproducible research, publishing scientific reports.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <!-- Part III -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part III. Data Analysis Methods</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Descriptive statistics and visualization.</li>
          <li>Linear and logistic regression.</li>
          <li>Multivariate analysis: PCA, EFA, Cluster Analysis.</li>
          <li>Latent Class Analysis (LCA) and Bayesian LCA.</li>
          <li>Big Data Analytics and Business Intelligence: from theory to application.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <!-- Part IV -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part IV. Data Visualization and Reporting</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Scientific and aesthetic principles of data visualization.</li>
          <li>Tool comparison: Excel, Power BI, ggplot2 (R), matplotlib (Python).</li>
          <li>Dynamic reporting with RMarkdown, Quarto.</li>
          <li>BI dashboards for health and social sectors.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <!-- Part V -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part V. Practical Applications</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Health: disease forecasting, vaccine supply chain management.</li>
          <li>Test management: data standardization, reducing processing time, and providing real-time dashboards.</li>
          <li>Community governance: survey analysis, budget monitoring.</li>
          <li>Education and society: analysis of training quality, labor market.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <!-- Part VI -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part VI. Case Studies</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Box 1: Business Intelligence in testing.</li>
          <li>Box 2: Big Data in health supply chain management (COVID-19).</li>
          <li>Box 3: Power BI dashboard for community surveys.</li>
          <li>Box 4: RShiny for public health data.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <!-- Part VII -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part VII. Data Infrastructure and Governance</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Data storage systems (cloud, open data, big data warehouse).</li>
          <li>Data integration from multiple sources.</li>
          <li>International standards: HL7, FHIR (health), SDMX (social).</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <!-- Part VIII -->
      <div class="card">
        <h3>Part VIII. Training and Scaling</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Design short-term training programs (3–5 days).</li>
          <li>Develop an open resource repository: datasets, scripts, video tutorials.</li>
          <li>Build a data practice community.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </section>

    <!-- 5. Development Methodology -->
    <section id="sec-5">
      <h2>5. Development Methodology</h2>

      <div class="card">
        <h3>Implementation Process</h3>
        <ol>
          <li>
            <strong>Systematic literature review:</strong>
            referencing recent studies on Big Data, Business Intelligence (BI), and community data management 
            (e.g., Dicuonzo, 2022; Al Nuaimi, 2024).
          </li>
          <li>
            <strong>Expert interviews &amp; workshops:</strong>
            working with statisticians, BI experts, public health officials to gather insights and practical requirements.
          </li>
          <li>
            <strong>Pilot implementation:</strong>
            applying the materials at hospitals, universities, and community organizations to evaluate effectiveness and applicability.
          </li>
          <li>
            <strong>Editing &amp; standardization:</strong>
            combining academic foundations with practical illustrations; standardizing terminology, processes, and lesson structures.
          </li>
          <li>
            <strong>Feedback loop:</strong>
            gathering feedback from pilot users, improving content and accompanying tools.
          </li>
        </ol>
      </div>

      <div class="callout">
        <p><strong>Open Access Publishing:</strong></p>
        <ul>
          <li>Release interactive <em>PDF</em> and <em>website</em>.</li>
          <li>Publicly release project <em>source code</em> (scripts, templates) on GitHub.</li>
          <li>Develop an online course (<em>MOOC</em>) with sample datasets and exercises.</li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </section>

    <!-- 6. Expected Outcomes -->
    <section id="sec-6">
      <h2>6. Expected Outcomes</h2>

      <div class="card">
        <h3>Deliverables</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>An academic–practical handbook (≈ 200–250 pages).</li>
          <li>A set of illustrative <em>case studies</em> with dashboards, source code, and sample data.</li>
          <li>An open online resource repository (documents, scripts, templates).</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <div class="card">
        <h3>Training Implementation</h3>
        <ul>
          <li>Organize at least <strong>03</strong> pilot training courses.</li>
          <li>Reach a minimum of <strong>200</strong> trainees (from various fields).</li>
        </ul>
      </div>

      <div class="card">
        <p><strong>Expected impact:</strong> Contribute to enhancing digital capacity for communities and social organizations, 
          promoting data-driven decision-making practices.</p>
      </div>
    </section>
